Award.AwardTitle: Using Assistive Device Design to Implement Corner Stone Project Based Learning

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: 1264321
PI: Reffeor

The objective of this project is to develop, disseminate and assess a cornerstone design learning strategy while teaching engineering students skills in developing specialized assistive devices for children with physical and mental disabilities. For this project cornerstone design is defined as comprehensive, project-based design education between the first year introduction classes and capstone design experiences that take place in the senior year. Projects will be implemented in the first and second semesters of the junior year as well as the first semester of the senior year. The prototypes and design documentation produced in previous classes will serve as design input for subsequent classes. However, each class will be required to interview users, care givers and physical therapists to refine the project specifications and to gain personal experience with the problems facing the users. Students will build a prototype of all or part of the required device in each course. Student teams in each course will give midterm and final presentations to professors and project stakeholders in order to solicit feedback on design alternatives under considerations and prototypes produced. The advantages of this approach include the delivery of a more refined and robust device to the user, student gain experience with preparing and working with design documentation and students will work through design iterations, a key component of complex design projects.

Intellectual Merit: Traditionally engineering design has been taught at the beginning and end of the engineering curriculum. First year students receive an introduction to design and senior students participate in capstone design classes. This project endeavors to develop a novel strategy of linking three existing courses to teach design skills to students to better prepare them for their capstone experience and their subsequent careers. In addition, students and faculty will work with users of assistive technology, caregivers and physical therapists to advance the field of assistive technology. The three course sequence allows teams to tackle difficult problems and develop innovative solutions because the time required iterations is built into the strategy.

Broader Impact: The ultimate goal of the project is to disseminate the results of the project and to facilitate other institutions in modifying and adopting the cornerstone design strategy to increase the pool engineers skilled in solving complex design problems. These well prepared engineers will use their skills in companies or as entrepreneurs to sustainably grow the economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project achieved five goals: 1)provide customized devices to meet the individual needs of persons with disabilities, 2) develop, refine and disseminate a cornerstone design strategy to improve design education at GVSU and other engineering programs, 3) increase interactions between community organizations that serve special needs populations and the university community, 4) introduce engineering students to a possible career path assisting those with disabilities such as biomedical engineering, and 5) commercialize products that address the needs of a community of users to increase the number of individuals helped and sustain the program beyond the duration of the grant.

In fulfillment of the first goal, a total of thirty-nine projects were completed over the five years grant.  Of these, some were iterations to further develop previous projects.  Some of the devices developed were designed to provide vestibular stimulation for children with limited mobility and/or autism.  These included play and mobility devices which allow small children to experience cause and effect while providing mobility, wheel-chair trainers which allow severely and multiply impaired children to practice driving a power wheelchair using the customized support of their own wheelchair, both free-standing and ceiling mounted motorized swings for larger children to allow children to swing without constant interaction from a caregiver a hugging vest for autistic children, and hugging and bouncy chairs for children up to 200 pounds to provide direct vestibular stimulation.  Additionally, a number of devices were designed to enhance people’s mobility including specialized motorized chairs for greater mobility in a classroom setting, early mobility systems to allow children to simultaneously practice cause and effect through motion control and freer play, an all-terrain mobility device to allow a child freedom of motion outdoors, a pool support to assist in supporting severely and multiply impaired students when exercising in a pool, a snowmobile suspension to enhance the competitiveness of an athlete competing in the X-games Snowmobile Adaptive SnoCross, exoskeletal arms to allow a child with spinal muscular atrophy, a slide support device to allow children who need trunk support to slide on a standard playground slide, and adaptive tricycles for students up to 300 pounds.  Finally projects were completed to enhance patient experiences in hospitals, provide better feedback for healthcare providers, and assist in bioengineering research.  These included a sit-to-stand device to allow easier transitioning from a hospital bed to the standing position, a training head array to allow children to learn to control a power wheelchair using head motion, a manual cough assist device to help people with limited lung function to expel secretions, a positive expiratory pressure (PEP) therapy device to assist patients with ineffective cough, a dental device to allow tongue control of a power wheelchair, a pressure mapping interface to allow better prosthetic fitting, a walker speed monitoring device to help prevent user falls, and a gel dispenser for EEG dielectric gel.

The primary medium for dissemination of the teaching methodology employed in completing these projects was journal papers and conference proceedings.  A total of five pedagogical papers and thirty-two technical papers were published as a result of the grant funding.  In addition to the dissemination of the work, eight professors spanning three engineering disciplines, physical therapy and occupational therapy were involved in leading these projects and developing the pedagogy.  In addition to dissemination of the work, in excess of five hundred high school students attended GVSU project days, viewed the projects, and interacted with the student engineers.

In fulfillment of goal three, the researchers worked with a total of six community organizations including two K-12 schools, three hospitals, one adaptive device company and the physical and occupational therapy departments at GVSU.  These community interactions provided quality projects as well as access to the customers allowing students to interact with their customers when developing their projects thereby learning the importance of understanding customer requirements and communicating with non-technical consumers.

A total of approximately two hundred engineering students worked to complete the projects funded by this grant.  Each of these students was exposed to assistive and biomedical device design as well as learning to work with non-technical project sponsors and satisfy individual device requirements.  Each of these elements are part of biomedical engineering. 

Although none of these projects have been directly commercialized, one patent has been filed.  This will hopefully lead to commercialization.

In short, this grant funded thirty-nine projects and allowed almost two hundred engineering students to experience designing products for real customers.  Additionally, pedagogy was developed and disseminated to further engineering education nationwide.
